headline: Stocks advance with focus on central banks, tech
summary: Global stock markets mostly advanced on Friday as traders reacted to central bank activity and easing concerns over the technology sector."Stocks in the tech sector have been boosted by yesterday's bumper earnings from Micron," noted Joshua Mahony, chief market analyst at trading group Scope Markets.

headline: Bubbles and Boring Bets: What’s Coming for Tech Stocks in 2026
summary: While tech giants like Alphabet Inc. and Nvidia Corp. delivered strong gains, unsung corners of the industry, like memory chips and hard disk drives, proved to be far better places for investors.  With the bull market in US stocks stretching into a fourth year, there are more concerns than ever about the sustainability of heavy spending on AI computing and whether the returns will justify the investments.

headline: At Goldman and Citadel Securities, the Santa Rally Has Believers
summary: If history is any guide, stocks will keep pushing higher: Since 1928, the S&P 500 has risen 75% of the time in the last two weeks of December, rising 1.3% on average, data compiled by Citadel Securities show.  While longer-term worries about the artificial-intelligence trade linger and valuations remain stretched, optimism over a strong economy and corporate profits is keeping investor sentiment upbeat.  Traders are snapping up bullish options on chipmakers and large-cap technology shares, according to Susquehanna International Group, while the retail crowd remains avid buyers of US stocks.

content.title: At Goldman and Citadel Securities, the Santa Rally Has Believers
content.summary: If history is any guide, stocks will keep pushing higher: Since 1928, the S&P 500 has risen 75% of the time in the last two weeks of December, rising 1.3% on average, data compiled by Citadel Securities show.  While longer-term worries about the artificial-intelligence trade linger and valuations remain stretched, optimism over a strong economy and corporate profits is keeping investor sentiment upbeat.  Traders are snapping up bullish options on chipmakers and large-cap technology shares, according to Susquehanna International Group, while the retail crowd remains avid buyers of US stocks.

headline: Google Cloud lands deal with Palo Alto Networks 'approaching $10 billion,' per source
summary: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec 19 (Reuters) - Alphabet's cloud computing unit and cybersecurity company Palo Alto Networks on Friday announced an ​expanded partnership that one source told Reuters was by far Google ‌Cloud's largest security services deal. The contract comprises a commitment by Palo Alto to pay a sum "approaching $10 ‌billion" to Google Cloud over several years, according to the person with direct knowledge of the matter.

content.title: Google Cloud lands deal with Palo Alto Networks 'approaching $10 billion,' per source
content.summary: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec 19 (Reuters) - Alphabet's cloud computing unit and cybersecurity company Palo Alto Networks on Friday announced an ​expanded partnership that one source told Reuters was by far Google ‌Cloud's largest security services deal. The contract comprises a commitment by Palo Alto to pay a sum "approaching $10 ‌billion" to Google Cloud over several years, according to the person with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: The Week in Numbers: Trump goes nuclear, TikTok sells up
summary:
STORY: From how Trump Media went nuclear, to TikTok's big U.S. sale...

This is the Week in Numbers.

:: Week in Numbers

:: $6 billion

$6 billion was the value of an unusual merger between President Donald Trump's social media company and a nuclear fusion firm.

It will see a tie-up between Trump Media and Google-backed TAE Technologies.

It came just days after fusion industry leaders asked for more federal funding from the U.S. Energy Department.

Peter Loge leads the Project on Ethics in Political Communication at The George Washington University.

"Any time a member of the president's family's name is on a commercial enterprise, it raises ethical questions. Are people buying the thing because the president's name is on it? Are people buying Trump branded products because they think it'll help him get close to the president or that the president will like them more?"

:: 80%

Just over 80% of TikTok's U.S. business will be sold to avoid a ban in the country.

Chinese owner ByteDance said it had signed a binding agreement with three major investors: Oracle, Silver Lake and Abu Dhabi-based MGX.

The deal will build a new U.S. company called TikTok USDS Joint Venture, with ByteDance holding just under a fifth of it.

:: 0.75%

0.75% is the new benchmark interest rate in Japan - up from a previous 0.5%.

It's the highest number seen in three decades, and the Bank of Japan showed a readiness for further hikes.

Policymakers also removed language that growth and price rises will stagnate due to higher U.S. tariffs.

Which showed their belief the country is on course to hit its 2% inflation target.

:: $19.5 billion

$19.5 billion is the writedown taken by Ford as it does a big rethink on electric cars. 

The auto giant killed several models and said it would pivot to gas and hybrid models. 

Its move comes after demand for EVs fell in the U.S., where the Trump administration has pulled incentives for buyers. 

:: $108.4 billion

And $108.4 billion was the hostile bid Warner Bros Discovery turned down from Paramount Skydance. 

Warner's board argued Paramount's offer misled shareholders over its financing. 

It argued the offer was 'inferior' to a merger agreement it already had in place with Netflix.

Whoever wins the bidding war will get hold of popular film franchises like 'Harry Potter' and 'DC Comics'.

content.title: The Week in Numbers: Trump goes nuclear, TikTok sells up
content.summary:

headline: Lovable: More Than Tripled Revenue Since Last Fund Raise
summary: Swedish AI startup Lovable has just closed a $330 million Series B funding round, valuing the company at $6.6 billion. Lovable specialises in so-called vibe coding and its AI-powered platform enables users to build applications without writing code. The latest fundraising round includes the VC arms of both Alphabet and Nvidia. Anton Osika, CEO and Co-Founder of Lovable, speaks to Bloomberg's Tom Mackenzie.

content.title: Lovable: More Than Tripled Revenue Since Last Fund Raise
content.description:
Swedish AI startup Lovable has just closed a $330 million Series B funding round, valuing the company at $6.6 billion. Lovable specialises in so-called vibe coding and its AI-powered platform enables users to build applications without writing code.
The latest fundraising round includes the VC arms of both Alphabet and Nvidia. Anton Osika, CEO and Co-Founder of Lovable, speaks to Bloomberg's Tom Mackenzie.

headline: Trump Media merger with nuclear fusion firm raises questions: analyst
summary:
STORY: On Thursday, U.S. President Donald Trump’s social media company announced an unusual $6 billion merger with TAE Technologies, a Google-backed nuclear fusion firm.

The news that Trump Media, which operates Truth Social, was getting into the nuclear energy business...

...came just days after fusion industry leaders met with representatives of the U.S. Energy Department asking for more federal funding.

And that rings some alarm bells says Peter Loge - a professor who heads up the Project on Ethics in Political Communication at The George Washington University.

“Any time the president's name is on a commercial enterprise, it raises ethical questions. Any time a member of the president's family's name is on a commercial enterprise, it raises ethical questions. Are people buying the thing because the president's name is on it? Are people buying Trump branded products because they think it'll help him get close to the president or that the president will like them more?"

The growing electricity needs of the technology industry have revived interest in nuclear power.

However, despite decades of efforts, nuclear fusion, often seen as a potentially cleaner and more reliable energy source, has yet to produce a commercially viable reactor.

The chief executive of TAE, Michl Binderbauer, was among the leaders who met U.S. Energy officials after the department formed its first-ever fusion office.

“And the question then becomes, 'Are they going to have a leg up? Is this company going to have a leg up because it is owned in part by a member of the Trump family? You know, will this company have an unfair competitive advantage when working with the federal government, when trying to get investors on board, because it is very publicly affiliated with with President Trump and his family.”

After his return to office this year, Trump's close relatives have pursued ventures leveraging his political power and policy shifts. 

For instance, the Trump family has piled up billions in crypto-related wealth as the president throws his support behind digital financial assets. 

Greater support from the federal government could potentially boost the value of the fusion investment as well.

Trump has 114 million shares in Trump Media, roughly 40% of the company. In the new merger, his ownership stake would be roughly 20%.

Trump Media mainly generates ad revenue off of Truth Social and has consistently lost money since it began. 

Loge says one option is for the president to remove his name from the companies to avoid looking improper.

"Of course, what the president is doing might be completely on the up and up. But we're at a point in our history where we need to both do and be seen to be doing the most noble thing possible. The most noble thing possible here is probably taking your name off of companies that are going to benefit from or even rely on the federal government.."

Trump Media chief executive Devin Nunes, a former Republican member of Congress, will be co-CEO of the new company, along with TAE chief Binderbauer.

The two, along with Donald Trump Jr., will sit on the merged company's board.

headline: Google Enlists Meta To Cut Nvidia Reliance
summary: Alphabet Inc.'s (NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google is stepping up its push to reshape the competitive dynamics of the AI chip market as demand for large-scale AI computing continues to surge. Google is teaming up more closely with Meta Platforms Inc (NASDAQ:META) as it looks to rely less on Nvidia Corp (NASDAQ:NVDA) for powering artificial intelligence. The company is working on software changes that make its own chips easier to use with PyTorch, the tool most AI developers already rely on, Reuters reported
